conversation.content: [measured] Please, have a seat in the examination chair, and we'll start with some basic tests to determine what's causing your vision problems.
[dryly] Vision problems. [chuckles] That's one way to describe not being able to read the fine print on contracts I've been signing for millennia.
[professionally calm] The aging process affects everyone differently, though I admit your case is somewhat unique given the, ah, extended timeline we're discussing here.
[wry] You're taking this remarkably well for someone who just had the Prince of Darkness walk into their strip mall optometry practice at three in the afternoon.
[methodically] Look straight ahead at the red dot, please, and try not to blink while I examine your retinal structure with this light.
You know, most mortals would be screaming or praying by now, but here you are adjusting your little machines like this is perfectly routine. [intrigued]
In thirty years of practice, I've learned that everyone who walks through that door needs help seeing clearly, regardless of their, let's say, metaphysical status.
The irony isn't lost on me that after eons of showing humanity their darkest truths, I can't even read my own handwriting anymore.
[calmly focused] Interesting. Your pupils aren't responding to light in the conventional way, but there's definitely a refractive error we can correct with the right prescription.
Refractive error sounds so clinical for what feels like cosmic punishment, though I suppose that's your expertise showing through. [exhales]
Read the third line down on the chart, and we'll work through each progressively smaller row until you can't distinguish the letters anymore. [adjusting equipment]
[squinting] E, F, P, T, O, Z... wait, that last one is either Z or 2, and honestly, the distinction matters when you're dealing with souls versus percentages.
[thoughtfully] Better or worse?
Better, definitely better, though 'better' is relative when you've spent eternity watching everything get progressively blurrier. [bitter laugh]
[gently] One or two?
[considering] Two makes the edges sharper, but one makes everything feel less harsh, like looking through forgiveness if that makes any sense.
[quietly methodical] The measurements indicate you'll need progressive lenses with a significant astigmatism correction, plus a coating to reduce glare from, well, flames.
[softly amazed] You're actually going to make me glasses. After everything I've done, all the suffering I've overseen, you're just going to help me see.
Vision is a fundamental need, and meeting fundamental needs without judgment is perhaps the most human thing we can do, wouldn't you say?
In all my existence, I never expected clarity to come from someone simply doing their job with compassion. [pause] Thank you.
